title-group.article-title: The Expression and Functionality of Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid 1 in Ovarian Endometriomas

article-meta.aff: 1Shanghai OB/GYN Hospital, Fudan University, Shanghai, China
2State Key Laboratory of Medical Neurobiology and Institute of Brain Science, Fudan University, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Sun-Wei Guo, Ph.D. Shanghai Obstetrics and Gynecology Hospital, Fudan University, 419 Fangxie Road, Shanghai 200011, China Email: hoxa10@gmail.com

abstract.p: Pains of various kinds—dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and dyspareunia—are the major complaints from women with endometriosis, representing the most debilitating nature of the disease. Despite extensive research, our understanding as how endometriosis causes pain is still fragmentary. In this study, we examined transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1)-positive nerve fibers in ectopic endometrium from women with ovarian endometriomas and in endometrium from women without endometriosis and correlated the density with the severity of dysmenorrhea in cases. We also performed an immunohistochemistry analysis of TRPV1 in ectopic and control endometrium. After finding TRPV1 immunoreactivity in ectopic endometrial cells, we further examined whether TRPV1 is functional in ectopic endometrial stromal cells (EESCs). We found that the density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in ectopic endometrial implants is higher than that in control endometrium and correlates positively with the severity of dysmenorrhea in women with endometriosis. In addition, TRPV1 expression was also found to be elevated significantly in EESCs when stimulated with inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandin E2 (PGE2 ) and tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α). Finally, we found that TRPV1 activation can induce the release of nitric oxide (NO) and interleukin 1β (IL-1β) in EESCs. The latter finding appears to be consistent with the reports of increased TRPV1 protein expression following peripheral inflammation. Our results suggest that the increased TRPV1-positive nerve fibers may integrate various stimuli on peripheral terminals or primary sensory neurons and generate hyperalgesia in endometriosis. The expression and functionality of TRPV1 in EESCs also suggest that TRPV1 may have neurosecretory functions that are yet to be elucidated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pains of various kinds—dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and dyspareunia—are the major complaints from women with endometriosis, representing the most debilitating nature of the disease. 1,2 Consequently, in treating women with endometriosis, one primary goal is to alleviate pain. Despite extensive research, our understanding as to how endometriosis causes pain is still fragmentary. In the last decade, there is a growing interest in the investigation of endometriosis-associated pain.

Anaf et al reported a close histological relationship between nerve density in rectovaginal endometriotic nodules3 and also a role of nerve infiltration and nerve growth factor (NGF) expression in deep adenomyotic nodules. 4 Berkley et al demonstrated in a rat model of endometriosis that endometriotic lesions induce an autonomic and sensory innervation, thus contributing to pain symptoms associated with endometriosis. 5,6 In peritoneal endometriosis, several groups have reported that the density of nerve fibers is increased in lesions, 7 which often is associated with pain8,9 and is reduced after hormonal treatment. 10 In deep infiltrating endometriosis which is associated more often with pelvic pains than other subtypes of endometriosis, the number and/or density of nerve fibers is also increased, 11 which is higher than that in other subtypes. 12,13 Similarly, ovarian endometriomas are found to be innervated mainly by sympathetic and sensory fibers, 14 and the nerve fiber density is shown to be higher in women with pain than in women without pain. 15

In all these published studies, the afferent nerve fibers are Aδ or C type stained by various markers such as S-100, calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP), substance P (SP), protein gene product 9.5 (PGP9.5), neuropeptide Y (NPY), vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), neurofilament (NF), acetylcholine (ACh), tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) NGF, and its receptors tyrosine kinase receptor A (TrkA) and p75. Interestingly, no report on the use of transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) in staining afferent nerve fibers has been published.

The capsaicin (CAP) receptor TRPV1 is a member of the transient receptor potential vanilloid family consisting of 7 members, TRPV1 to TRPV7. As a nonselective cation channel, TRPV1 is expressed by sensory neurons and responds to noxious heat (>43°C), acid (pH <5.9), protons, vanilloids, and various endogenous ligands. TRPV1 activity is enhanced by various inflammatory mediators such as NGF, somatostatin, bradykinin, prostaglandins, serotonin, and others, implicating an essential role of TRPV1 in integrating different signal pathways for mediating nociceptor sensitization. 16 TRPV1 has been shown to play a role in inflammatory hyperalgesia in animal models. 17 Inflammation-induced ongoing pain is shown to be driven by TRPV1-sensitive afferents. 18 TRPV1 is synthesized in sensory neurons in the dorsal root ganglia (DRG) and transported along their peripheral axons to both peripheral and viscera and centrally to the spinal dorsal horn. Activation of TRPV1 also leads to local release of sensory neuropeptides including CGRP and SP, which, in turn, activate their effector cell receptors and contribute to the process of neurogenic inflammation. TRPV1 also is expressed in nonsensory cells, although its significance is currently unclear.

In women with endometriosis, TRPV1 immunoreactivity is shown to be elevated in peritoneal endometriotic foci and is correlated with the presence of chronic pelvic pain. 19 In a mouse model of endometriosis, the induction of endometriosis resulted in increased immunoreactivity to TRPV1 in eutopic endometrium, but treatment with a histone deacetylase inhibitor reduced the TRPV1 staining, along with improved tolerance to noxious thermal stimulation. 20 In adenomyosis, TRPV1 staining is significantly increased in ectopic endometrium as compared with normal endometrium. In fact, TRPV1 immunoreactivity is found to be positively correlated with the severity of dysmenorrhea. 21 While the significance of TRPV1 expression in nonsensory cells in endometriosis remains unclear, it is not known whether TRPV1 is functional.

In this study, we examined TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in ectopic endometrium in cases and normal endometrium in controls and correlated the density with the severity of dysmenorrhea in cases. We also carried out an immunohistochemistry (IHC) analysis of TRPV1 in ectopic and normal endometrium. After finding TRPV1 immunoreactivity in ectopic endometrial stromal cells (EESCs) and epithelial cells, we examined whether prostaglandin E2 (PGE2 ) and tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) stimulation can induce TRPV1 expression in primary endometriotic stromal cells and whether CAP can increase intracellular calcium concentration and evoke membrane currents. Finally, we examined whether TRPV1 activation can induce the release of nitric oxide (NO) and interleukin 1β (IL-1β) in these cells. The purpose of this study was severalfold: to correlate TRPV1-positive nerve fiber density with the severity of dysmenorrhea, to identify the localization of TRPV1 in ectopic endometrial implants, and to examine whether it is functional or not in nonneuronal cells in ovarian endometriomas.

sec.title: Patients and IHC
sec.p: Sixty-three patients with ovarian endometriomas were included for this study. These patients underwent conservative or semiradical surgery via either laparotomy or laparoscopy at Shanghai OB/GYN Hospital, Fudan University from 2008 to 2009. All diagnoses were confirmed histologically by experienced pathologists. Patients concurrent with adenomyosis were excluded. For each patient, information was collected through reading medical charts and interviewing patients on age at surgery, severity of dysmenorrhea, presence of myoma, if any, laterality of endometrioma, size of endometrioma (defined to be the diameter in centimeter of the largest cyst), the Revised American Fertility Society Classification of Endometriosis (rAFS) scores and stage, and the menstrual phase during which the surgery was performed. As a custom, the severity of pain was quantified by verbal descriptor scale, as none, mild, moderate, or severe. For controls, we collected, after informed consent, endometrial tissue samples through curettage from 24 women with tubal infertility or surgically diagnosed benign ovarian cysts but without any clinical history or diagnosis of endometriosis, adenomyosis, or myoma. None of the controls complained dysmenorrhea or other forms of pelvic pain. The selection of the controls was based solely on menstrual phase and age besides disease status. This study was approved by the institutional ethics review board of Shanghai OB/GYN Hospital.

Serial 4-μm sections were obtained from each block, with the first resultant slide being stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) to confirm pathologic diagnosis, and the subsequent slides stained for polyclonal rabbit anti-TRPV1 antibody (ab63083, diluted at 1:300, Abcam, Cambridge, UK). Routine deparaffinization and rehydration procedures were performed. For antigen retrieval, the slides were heated at 98°C in an EDTA buffer (pH 9.0) for a total of 30 minutes and cooled naturally to the room temperature. Endogenous peroxidase was blocked by incubation in 0.3% weight/volume (w/v) hydrogen peroxide in methanol. After rehydration in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), sections were then incubated with the primary antibody overnight at 4°C. After the slides were rinsed, the horseradish peroxixdase (HRP)-labeled secondary antibody Supervision TM Universal (Anti-Mouse/Rabbit) Detection Reagent (Shanghai Gene Tech Company, Shanghai; Cat No: GK500705) was incubated at room temperature for 30 minutes. The bound antibody complexes were stained for 3 to 5 minutes or until appropriate for microscopic examination with diaminobenzidine and then counterstained with hematoxylin and mounted. To further identify the TRPV1 immunoreactive nerve fibers, the frozen sections were stained again with indirect immunofluorescence method with a secondary antibody of goat TRITC anti-rabbit antibody (1:100, Beckman, Urbana, Illinois), counterstained with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) and then were covered with a coverslip.

Each staining run incorporated a positive control slide from the DRG and mouse. A negative control was obtained using preimmune immunoglobulin G (IgG) instead of the primary antibody. Immunoreactive staining was characterized quantitatively by digital image analysis using the Image Pro-Plus 6.0 (Media Cybernetics, Inc, Bethesda, MD, USA) as reported in Wang-Tilz et al,22 without prior knowledge of any of the clinicopathological information of the patients being evaluated.

The procedure of microvascular density quantification as described by Weidner et al23 was used to count the number of TRPV1 immunoreactive nerve fibers in ectopic endometrial lesions. The entire section was scanned at low power (×100) to identify hot spots, which represent the areas of highest innervation followed by nerve fiber counting on 5 randomly chosen fields (×200) of the “hot spots” by the same investigator without any knowledge of the pain status of the patient being evaluated. The total number of nerve fibers was divided by the total number of hot spots on each section to obtain an average of nerve fibers per hot spot (∼1 mm2 per spot). The results were expressed as the mean (±SD) number of nerve fibers per mm2 in each specimen.

sec.title: Tissue Collection, Cell Preparation, Culture, and Reagents
sec.p: The isolation and culturing of primary ESCs were carried out as previously described. 24 Briefly, normal primary ESCs were isolated from endometrial biopsies obtained from either controls (normal ESCs [NESCs]) or linings of ovarian endometrioma cyst (EESCs). The tissues were minced into 1-mm2 fragments with sterile scissors and the isolation of the stromal cells was conducted by digesting endometrial fragments with 0.25% type I collagenase for 30 minutes in a shaking water bath at 37°C. The digestate was filtered through a 38-µm stainless steel sieve to remove the glands. Purification of the stromal cell-enriched fraction was accomplished with a Percoll gradient and incubated for 30 minutes at 37°C in a standard humidified 95% air/5% CO2 incubator. During this period, the ESC, but not the other cell types, were attached to polystyrene tissue culture plastic. The ESCs were grown in the DMEM/F12 (GIBCO, GrandIsland, New York) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (PAA Laboratories, Linz, Austria) and 10% penicillin/streptomycin (Invitrogen, Lofer, Austria). Before drug treatment, phenol red-free DMEM/F12 medium was replenished. Anti-TRPV1 rabbit polyclonal antibody was purchased from Abcam (ab63083, Cambridge, UK). Capsaicin, capsazepine (CZP), PGE2, and TNF-α were purchased from Sigma (St Louis, MO, USA).

sec.title: RNA Isolation, Quantitative Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction
sec.p: The total RNA was extracted from treated and untreated cells with Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) following the manufacturer’s instructions. The RNA preparation was then treated with Dnase1 (Invitrogen) and 1 μg RNA was reverse transcribed into complementary DNA (cDNA) with a reverse transcription kit (Takara, Shuzo, Kyoto, Japan). Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis was conducted using the Applied Biosystems 7000 Sequence Detection System (Foster City, California) equipped with a 96-well optical reaction plate. The PCRs were set up using 10 μL SYBR Green PCR Master Mix (Takara), 0.8 μL of 10 μmol/L primer mixture, and 2 μL cDNA template. The real-time PCR conditions were as follows: 95°C for 30 seconds followed by 35 cycles at 95°C for 5 seconds, and 60°C for 31 seconds. The primers used in the present study were as follows: TRPV1: forward primer 5’-CAG CAG CGAGAC CCC TAA-3’, reverse primer 5-ACT TGG CTG AGGACG TCC-3; glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH): forward primer 5’GGCATG GAC TGT GGT CAT GA-3’, reverse primer 5’-TGCACCACCAACTGCTTAGC-3’. All real-time PCR experiments were carried out in triplicate, and a mean value was used for the determination of messenger RNA (mRNA) expression levels. A negative control containing water instead of sample cDNA was applied to each real-time plate. At the end of the PCR run, the threshold value (CT ) for each of these genes was set using the ABI PRISM 7000 software program (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA). The relative expression of mRNA was calculated using the comparative CT method.

sec.title: Western Blot Analysis
sec.p: The cultured primary NESCs and EESCs, treated or untreated, were rinsed 3 times with cold PBS and then harvested by a cell scraper. The cells were lysed with complete lysis-M buffer (Roche, Nutley, New Jersey). The homogenates were then spun at 12 000g for 30 minutes and the supernatants were determined using the bicinchoninic acid (BCA) method. Protein samples (30 μg) were loaded onto an 8% sodium dodecyl sulfate–polyacrylamide gel, electrophoresed, and then transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane. Afterward the blotting membranes were blocked with PBST (PBS/0.1%Tween-20) (80 mmol/L Na2 HPO4, 20 mmol/L NaH2 PO4, 100 mmol/L NaCl, 0.1% Tween 20, pH 7.5) plus 5% nonfat milk and incubated overnight with the primary antibody at 4°C. After washing, the blots were incubated in HRP-conjugated secondary antibody for 1 hour at room temperature. The blots were detected with the chemiluminiscence reagent (SuperSignal West Pico, Rockford, Illinois).

sec.title: Patch Clamp Electrophysiology
sec.p: The cultured primary EESCs selected for recordings were within 2 to 4 passages, and the resting membrane potential was found to be more negative than −60 mV. The patch electrodes with a resistance of 2 to 5 MΩ were pulled from borosilicate glass capillaries (the inner diameter (ID) ID = 0.86 mm, outer diameter (OD) OD = 1.5 mm, Sutter Instruments, Novato, California) using a micropipette puller (P-97, Sutter Instruments). Whole-cell patch clamp recordings were carried out using an Axonpatch 200B amplifier (Axon Instruments, Union City, California). After the whole-cell configuration was established, the cell membrane capacitance and series resistance were compensated (>80%). The leak currents were subtracted using the online P/4 protocol. All experiments were performed at room temperature (about 25°C). Signals were filtered at 2 kHz and digitized at 10 kHz. For the whole-cell recording, the pipette solution contained the following (in mmol/L): KCl 150, MgCl2 2.5, N-2-hydroxyethylpiperazine-N-2′-ethanesulfonic acid (HEPES) 10, Ethylene glycol-bis-(,8- aminoethylether)N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid (EGTA) 0.2, MgATP 2, and Na2GTP 0.3 (pH adjusted to 7.4 with KOH). The external solution contained NaCl (150 mmol/L), KCl (5 mmol/L), CaCl2 (2 mmol/L), MgCl2 (1 mmol/L), HEPES (10 mmol/L), and glucose (10 mmol/L), and the pH adjusted to 7.4 with NaOH. Throughout the experiment, the drug solution was delivered to the cells via a fast perfusion system (ALA-VM8, Scientific Instrument Inc, Westbury, New York). The distance between the cells and the silicon barrel tip (OD/ID = 200/100 μm) was ∼200 μm. Inhibitors were applied to the chamber for 30 minutes before the addition of CAP. Data were presented as the mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM) or as numerical values ± SE, with n indicating the number of cells in a given series of experiments. Data were analyzed using the Clampfit 10.2 software (Axon Instruments).

sec.title: Measurement of Intracellular Calcium
sec.p: The cultured primary ESCs were grown to 70% to 80% confluency and then washed with Ringer solution that had the following composition: 140 mmol/L NaCl, 5 mmol/L KCl, 2 mmol/L CaCl2, 1 mmol/L MgCl2, 10 mmol/L HEPES, and 10 mmol/L glucose, adjusted to pH = 7.4 with NaOH. Cells were loaded with the calcium-sensitive indicator fluo3/acetoxymethyl ester (fluo-3/AM, Molecular Probes, Inc; Cat# F1241, Carlsbad, California) at a concentration of 5 μmol/L in Ringer solution for 60 minutes. The Fluo-3/AM was diluted from a concentrated stock solution (1 mmol/L) dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). After loading, the cells were washed 3 times with Ringer solution and then placed in a recording chamber and were then superfused with Ringer solution. The calcium image was recorded by a confocal laser scanning microscope (Leica TCS-NT, Heidelberg, Germany). The intracellular Ca2+ level was represented by the fluo3 fluorescence intensity. Fluo3 fluorescence was excited at 488 nm, and the emitted light was measured at 530 nm. Fluorescent intensity readings were made at 3-second intervals following the addition of an agonist to the cells. The peak increase in relative fluorescent units (RFUs) over the baseline fluorescence (ΔF/F0) was calculated and analyzed with TCS-NT software (Leica).

sec.title: Measurement of Nitrite/Nitrate and IL-1β Production
sec.p: The cultured primary EESCs were inoculated in 6-well plates at a concentration of 5 × 105 cells/mL and a total volume of 1 mL. At 24 hours after culture, the culture medium without serum was replaced and these cells were starved for 12 hours and then stimulated for 24 hours. A NO colorimetric assay kit (#k262, BioVision, California) was used to measure total gas phase NO (nitrite/nitrate) in the culture medium according to the vendor’s instructions. Briefly, NO was rapidly oxidized to nitrite and nitrate which were used to quantitate the NO production. This kit provides an accurate and convenient measure of total nitrate/nitrite in a simple 2-step process. The first step converts nitrate into nitrite using nitrate reductase. The second step uses Griess reagents to convert nitrite into a deep purple azo compound. The amount of the azo chromophore accurately reflects the NO amount in the sample. The medium was collected 24 hours after drug treatment, the amount of IL-1β was measured using a Quantikine IL-1β ELISA kit (Shanghai Jitai Biotech Company, Shanghai, China). After removing the media, cells were typsinized and counted to normalize for cell density.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The comparison of distributions of continuous variables between 2 or more groups was made using the Wilcoxon or Kruskal test, respectively, and the paired Wilcoxon test was used when the before–after comparison was made for the same group of participants. Pearson or Spearman rank correlation coefficient was used when evaluating the correlations between 2 variables when both variables are continuous or when at least 1 variable is ordinal.

Jonckheere trend test was used to test whether there is any association between the severity of pelvic pain and other factors of interest. To evaluate the factors that are associated with the severity of dysmenorrhea, we used the Cox regression model for the discrete or grouped survival time data without censoring. 25 The severity of dysmenorrhea was coded as 0 for none, 1 for mild, 2 for moderate, and 3 for severe.
P values of less than .05 were considered statistically significant. All computations were made with R 2.13.1 (www.r-project.org).26

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: The characteristics and the 63 patients with ovarian endometriomas (cases) and 24 controls were listed in Table 1. It can be seen that the 2 groups were comparable with respect to age and menstrual phase at which the tissue samples were harvested.

tr.th: Statistical Significance of the Difference Between the 2 Groups

fn.p: Abbreviations: NA, not applicable; SD, standard deviation.

sec.title: TRPV1 IHC in Ectopic and Normal Endometrium
sec.p: TRPV1 staining in normal and ectopic endometrium was seen mostly in cytoplasm (Figure 1). While TRPV1 staining levels in epithelium and stroma were highly correlated (r = .97, P = 3.6 × 10−15, and r = .60, P = 1.6 × 10−7, in control and ectopic endometrium, respectively), the immunoreactivity to TRPV1 was significantly higher in epithelium than stroma in both normal and ectopic endometrium (P = 2.4 × 10−7 and P = 4.2 × 10−11, respectively), consistent with a previous report. 19 There was no difference in TRPV1 staining in either normal endometrium or ectopic endometrium with respect to menstrual phase, irrespective of cell types (all 4 P values >.66).

caption.p: Immunohistochemical staining of transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) in ectopic and normal endometrium. A, Negative control using preimmune serum instead of the primary antibody. B, Staining in an ectopic endometrial tissue. C, Positive control: staining in DRG of rat (×400). D, Staining in normal endometrium. Magnification: ×200 unless otherwise indicated.

sec.p: The TRPV1 staining was significantly higher in ectopic endometrium than that in normal endometrium in both epithelial and stromal components (P = 2.2 × 10−8 and P = 2.6 × 10−5, respectively; Figure 2A and B). Among women with endometriosis, the TRPV1 staining levels in stromal cells, but not in epithelial cells, in ectopic endometrium was associated with the severity of dysmenorrhea (P = .027 and P = .15 for stroma and epithelium, respectively, by the Jonckheere trend test). In fact, there was a positive correlation between the severity of pain and TRPV1 staining levels in stromal, but not epithelial, cells (Spearman r = .29, P = .023 for stromal cells and r = .20, P = .12 for epithelial cells; Figure 2C and D). There was a statistically significant difference in TRPV1 staining levels in both stromal and epithelial cells between women who complained of dysmenorrhea and who did not (p = 0.004 and p = 0.02, respectively).

caption.p: Box plots of transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) staining levels in different cell types by tissue group. A, Stroma component. B, Epithelium component. C, Ectopic endometrial stromal component. D, Ectopic endometrial epithelial component.

sec.title: Correlation of Dysmenorrhea Severity and the TRPV1-Positive Nerve Fiber Density
sec.p: We found that the severity of dysmenorrhea correlated positively with the size of ovarian cysts (Spearman r = .29, p = .021; p = .021 also using Jonckheere trend test) but not rAFS scores or stage (r = .01, P = .95 and r = −.05, P = .71). Laterality of the ovarian cysts did not correlate with pain severity (P = .72).

We also found TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in and/or surrounding the endometriotic lesions (Figure 3). Table 2 showed the percentage and mean density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in lesions in women with various severity of dysmenorrhea. TRPV1-positive nerve fibers were rarely found in normal endometrium (data not shown). In sharp contrast, they were found surrounding ectopic endometrium, and the density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers was found to be positively associated with the severity of dysmenorrhea (P = .002, Jonckheere trend test; Table 2 and Figure 4). In fact, the density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers surrounding endometriotic lesions correlated positively with the severity of dysmenorrhea (Spearman r = .42, P = .0007; Figure 4). The nerve fiber density did not correlate with either rAFS score or rAFS stage (r = .03, P = .80, and Spearman r = .17, P = .20, respectively).

caption.p: Transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1)-positive nerve fibers surrounding the endometriotic lesions. A, The arrows indicate nerve fibers near the ectopic glandular epithelium. The truncated arrow indicates ectopic glandular epithelium. B, TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in the fibrotic interstitial of ectopic endometrium. Magnification: ×200.
Box plot of the density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers surrounding endometriotic lesions in women with different severity of dysmenorrhea.
The Percentage and Density of TRPV1 Immunoreactive Nerve Fibers in Ectopic Endometrium of Women With Endometriosis

sec.p: A multivariate analysis using the Cox regression model involving TRPV1 staining levels in stroma and/or epithelium components (adjusted by menstrual phase), density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in and/or surrounding endometriotic lesions, along with age, rAFS score, and cyst size, found that cyst size (P = .014) and the density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers (P = .024) were the only 2 variables positively associated with the severity of dysmenorrhea.

sec.title: The Effect of Inflammatory Mediators on TRPV1 Expression in EESCs
sec.p: We next examined the effect of PGE2 and TNF-α, the 2 common inflammatory mediators in endometriosis, on TRPV1 expression in EESCs. Using cultured primary EESCs, we evaluated TRPV1 gene and protein expression levels in response to stimulation with PGE2 (10−8 mol/L) and TNF-α (1 μmol/L), which were the normally used concentrations. 27,28 The real-time RT-PCR analysis showed that, when stimulated with PGE2 for 6, 12, and 24 hours, TRPV1 expression increased by 3.2-, 3.7-, and 3.1-fold in EESCs, respectively, as compared with unstimulated cells (all P values <.05). When stimulated with TNF-α, TRPV1 expression was increased in a time-dependent fashion, by 1.9-, 2.9-, and 3.5-fold (Figure 5A). Consistent with the gene expression data, the Western blot analysis showed that the incubation with PGE2 and TNF-α for 24 hours resulted in significant increase in TRPV1 protein expression by 2.8- and 2.2-fold, respectively (both P values <.05; Figure 5B).

caption.p: Expression of TRPV1 in EESC stimulated by PGE2 and TNF-α at different time course with real-time PCR (A) and Western blot analysis (B). P < .05 as compared with the control. TRPV1 indicates transient receptor potential vanilloid 1; EESCs, ectopic endometrial stromal cells; PGE2, prostaglandin E2; TNF-α, tumor necrosis factor-α.

sec.title: Effects of CAP on the Intracellular Calcium Concentration in EESCs
sec.p: Given positive TRPV1 staining and also PGE2 - and TNFα-induced TRPV1 upregulation in EESCs, we wondered whether TRPV1 in EESCs is functional or not, and we thus quantified CAP-evoked Ca2+ influx in these cells. We tested whether the intracellular calcium concentration ([Ca2+]i ) can be influenced by CAP by performing fluo3/AM-based calcium imaging experiments in EESCs. Application of 1 μmol/L CAP via bath superfusion significantly reduced the fluorescence intensity in EESCs by 21.5% on average (Figure 6A). The time to bottom was mostly within 1 minute and this effect was washed out by a rinse with balanced salt solution (Figure 6B), without desensitization after repetitive perfusions. Over 90% of monitored cells were found to be responsive to CAP simulation, and the pretreatment with CZP (10 μmol/L) for 30 minutes abrogated this effect. CAP-induced decrease in [Ca2+]i was attenuated by high concentrations of Ca2+ in external solution (data not shown). The EESC showed greater capacity of Ca2+ outflux as compared with NESC when treated with the same concentration of CAP (P < .05; Figure 6C). Pretreatment with PGE2 for 30 minutes significantly increased the Ca2+ outflux induced by CAP in EESC (P < .05; Figure 6D).

caption.p: Calcium imaging. A, Capsaicin-induced decrease in Ca2+ in EESCs. Images were taken before (left) and after (right) application of capsaicin. B, Fluorescent intensity response to consecutive application of capsaicin, washout could restore. Different curves mean different cells in different region in the same plate. C, Ectopic ESC showed greater capacity of Ca2+ outflux compared with normal ESC when treated with capsaicin (ΔF/F0 : The peak increase in relative fluorescent units [RFU] over the baseline fluorescence; P < .05). D, Pretreatment with PGE2 increases the Ca2+ outflux in EESC induced by capsaicin (P < .05). EESCs indicates ectopic endometrial stromal cells; CAP, capsaicin; PGE2, prostaglandin E2.

sec.title: Effects of CAP on the Membrane Currents of the EESC
sec.p: Because CAP evoked calcium reduction in EESCs, we next determined whether CAP can induce membrane currents in EESCs. To see this, we performed a whole-cell configuration patch clamp experiment. We found that incubation of EESCs with CAP (1 μmol/L) resulted in an apparent outward current (ranging from 20 pA to 170 pA, SD = 55, n = 20) in 65% of EESCs, suggesting that TRPV1 is functional in EESCs when activated by CAP. In particular, when CAP was repeatedly applied for 5 times at a duration of 3 seconds/min, there was no obvious desensitization as evidenced by the output CAP-induced currents (Figure 7). Moreover, the outward currents induced by CAP was completely blocked by pretreatment with a TRPV1 antagonist, CZP (10 μmol/L), for 30 minutes (data not shown).

caption.p: Capsaicin at a concentration of 1μmol/L induces apparent outward currents in EESC. When capsaicin was repeatedly applied for 5 times at 3 s/min, no apparent desensitization of TRPV1 currents was found. EESCs indicates ectopic endometrial stromal cells; CAP, capsaicin.

sec.title: Activation of TRPV1 Induces NO and IL-1β Release
sec.p: To address whether activation of TRPV1 would promote the production of NO, a liquid-soluble gaseous free radical, and IL-1β, a proinflammatory cytokine, in EESC, these cells were treated with CAP (1 μmol/L), CAP (1 μmol/L) + CZP (3 μmol/L), CZP (3 μmol/L), or vehicle only, and NO and IL-1β production in the cell supernatants were quantitated. Treatment of EESC with CAP significantly increased NO and IL-1β production by 1.5- and 20-fold (both P values <.001; Figure 8), respectively, and this effect was abrogated by pretreatment with CZP (3 μmol/L; both P values <.05). Capsazepine also slightly but significantly increased the NO and IL-1β release (both P values <.02).

caption.p: Transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) stimulation increased NO (A) and IL-1β (B) production in EESC. A: *compared with control, P < .05; #compared with the capsaicin group, P < .05; B: *compared with control, P < .05; #compared with the capsaicin group, P < .05. CAP indicates capsaicin; CZP, capsazepine; NO, nitric oxide; IL-1β, interleukin 1β; EESCs, ectopic endometrial stromal cells.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In this study, we have determined immunoreactivity of TRPV1 in both normal and ectopic endometrium and found that the TRPV1 expression in ectopic endometrium was significantly higher than that in the normal endometrium. The density of TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in ectopic endometrial implants correlates positively with the severity of dysmenorrhea in women with ovarian endometriomas. In addition, TRPV1 expression is also found to be increased significantly in cultured primary EESC when stimulated with inflammatory mediators such as PGE2 and TNF-α. The latter finding appears to be consistent with the reports of increased TRPV1 protein expression following peripheral inflammation in other cell types. 29
–32 Although these ectopic stromal cells are non-neuronal cells, they may have neurosecretory functions that are yet to be elucidated.

We have also demonstrated that CAP evoked Ca2+ outflux and induced outward currents in EESC, and the effects can be inhibited by CZP, a TRPV1 antagonist. Although the reason as to why TRPV1 in EESCs has a Ca2+ flux and a TRPV1-current direction different from that in DRG is still unclear, our results nonetheless suggest that EESCs possess functional Ca2+-permeable TRPV1 that can be activated by CAP or possibly by other pain or proinflammatory mediators in endometriotic lesions. Pretreatment with PGE2 could potentiate the CAP-evoked Ca2+ outflux in EESCs. The EESCs have higher Ca2+ outflux as compared with NESCs when stimulated by CAP. It is possible that EESCs have greater amounts of TRPV1 or have more sensitized TRPV1 under the stimulation of inflammatory mediators. Tominaga et al found that PGE2 increased or sensitized TRPV1 responses through EP1 or IP receptors, respectively, predominantly in a PKC-dependent manner in both HEK293 cells expressing TRPV1 and mouse DRG neurons. 33 Both PGE2 -induced thermal hyperalgesia and inflammatory nociceptive responses were diminished in TRPV1-deficient mice and EP1 - or IP-deficient mice. Thus, the potentiation or sensitization of TRPV1 activity through EP1 or IP activation might be one important mechanism underlying the peripheral nociceptive actions of PGE2.

The presence of TRPV1 has been established in the dorsal root, trigeminal, nodose ganglia, 34 and brain, 35,36 in addition to the originally reported DRG. 37 Subsequently, several vanilloid receptor variants and homologues have been recognized in not only neural but also various non-neural cells, such as bronchial epithelial cells, 38 keratinocytes in epidermis, 39,40 and urinary bladder epithelial cells. 41 These observations suggest that TRPV1 is more broadly distributed than previously thought, although its functional role in these cells has yet to be elucidated.

It is well documented that CAP excites nociceptors by increasing the Ca2+ permeability of the plasma membrane based on its effects on Ca2+ influx. 17 Studies of both native and cloned TRPV1 channels have revealed several mechanisms that modulate their responsiveness to noxious stimuli. A single prolonged application of CAP, for example, leads to a gradual reduction over the course of seconds to minutes, a calcium-dependent process referred to as desensitization. 42 In this study, we have demonstrated that, in contrast to sensory cells, CAP evoked Ca2+ outflux and induced outward currents in EESCs. Moreover, there was no apparent desensitization of the CAP-induced currents in EESCs. These observations indicate that the TRPV1 expressing in the nonsensory EESCs may have a topological structure and function different from that in sensory neurons. Given the observed Ca2+ outflux, we speculate that the intracellular Ca2+ concentration within EESCs might be much higher than that in their extracellular environment, but its pathophysiological significance is yet to be elucidated. The Ca2+ outflux by the concentration gradient was induced when the TRPV1 channels were activated by CAP. The calcium-dependent process referred to as desensitization may be prevented by the opposite Ca2+ flux. Regardless, this somewhat novel observation suggests that TRPV1 channels in EESCs may function differently from that in sensory neurons. However, the exact mechanism of this function and its significance awaits future investigation.

A large body of evidence indicates that NO contributes to the processing of nociceptive signals in the spinal cord. Several animal studies 43,44 have consistently shown that inhibition of NO synthesis can significantly reduce both inflammatory and neuropathic pain. Poblete et al showed that low concentrations of anandamide elicit the release of NO mediated predominantly by the activation of endothelial TRPV1. 45 Nitric oxide is known to be involved in inflammation and neoangiogenesis. 46,47 It has been shown that increased NO synthesis in endometriosis. 48
–51 In our study, we found that stimulation of TRPV1 in EESCs increases NO production, suggesting that activated TRPV1 in endometriotic lesions may facilitate NO production, thus contributing to angiogenesis, inflammation, and increased afferent sensing of pain.

The increase in IL-1β production in endometriosis has long been reported. 52 –54 Interleukin 1β can further induce other proinflammatory mediators such as monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), 55 IL-8, 56 regulated upon activation normal T cell expressed and secreted, RANTES, 57,58 and cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) 59 in endometriosis. The finding that TRPV1 is expressed and functional in EESCs, along with the finding that TRPV1 activation increases the IL-1β production suggests that TRPV1 activation may also contribute to the increased IL-1β production in endometriosis.

Taken together, the finding that stimulation with inflammatory mediators such as PGE2 and TNF-α in EESC induces TRPV1 expression and that TRPV1 activation induces NO and IL-1β release seems to suggest that a feed-forward mechanism may exist in ectopic endometrium, perpetuating the increased production of proinflammatory cytokines as well as enhanced pain perception in endometriosis. Future studies are warranted to delineate the precise functions of TRPV1 activation in EESCs.

Although we used extrinsic agonist to stimulate TRPV1 in our in vivo studies, a variety of inflammatory mediators including prostaglandins, NGF, bradykinin, ATP, lipoxygenase products, and adenosine act via second messenger molecules such as PKA and PKC to induce TRPV1 sensitization. In addition, inflammation and hypoxia—both are present in endometriosis—are associated with tissue acidification, further potentiating TRPV1 activity. Taken together, all these factors can facilitate TRPV1 activation, 60 –62 and, in turn, cause pains of various kinds in endometriosis. Therefore, TRPV1 could be functional very likely under the stimulation of inflammatory mediators, hypoxia, and some endogenous ligands such as prolactin, 63 the serum level of which has been shown to be elevated in endometriosis. 64

As a polymodal nocitransducer and a pain integrator that is widely expressed within pain transmitting/modulating areas of the peripheral and central nervous system, TRPV1 is activated by an array of endogenous inflammatory agents besides CAP. 65 It is expressed in DRG, trigeminal, and vagal sensory ganglia in small C and Aδ sensory fibers which contain SP and CGRP, as well as co-localize with TrkA. Its activation is a key event in mechanisms of peripheral nociceptive sensitization. 66 –68 Once activated, it reduces its threshold for detecting painful stimuli. 69 Viewed in this lens, the elevated TRPV1-positive nerve fibers in ectopic endometrium, along with the correlation of TRPV1-positive nerve fiber density and dysmenorrhea severity as we reported here, simply suggest that TRPV1 might play a role in endometriosis-related pain.

Yet one limitation of this study is that we did not examine TRPV1 expression in other sites besides ectopic endometrium. One main reason for this drawback is the ethical challenge in collecting tissue samples from women who have not had children. It has been reported that in women with chronic pain, with or without endometriosis, the uteri endometrium, myometrium, isthmus, cervix, and vagina may all be reinnervated, 6,70
–73 which has been theorized to be the consequence of tissue injury resulting from difficult vaginal deliveries and/or straining during defacation74 or from microtraumatization. 75 These injuries, followed by denervation and reinnervation, result in accompanying changes in the central nervous system (central sensitization), 74 as seems to be the case in endometriosis. 76 As central sensitization is known to be mediated by a series of changes that eventually lead to an amplified or somewhat exaggerated excitatory transmission at the synapses between primary afferent nerve fibers and second-order sensory neurons in the dorsal horns of the spinal cord, 77 perhaps future animal studies may help to shed light on how tissue injury exactly promotes neurotrophic activity and through what mechanisms. Epidemiological studies may also be warranted in the future to quantify the risk, if any, of developing endometriosis in women who had difficult vaginal deliveries, extended period of straining during defacation, or other types of injuries. Currently, an outstanding challenge is to determine how these seemingly diverse aberrations cause pain of various kinds in endometriosis.

In sum, we have demonstrated that TRPV1-positive nerve fiber density correlates positively with the severity of dysmenorrhea in women with ovarian endometriomas. In addition, we have shown the presence of functional TRPV1 in ectopic endometrium and suggested its possible role as an initial pain sensor for noxious inflammatory stimuli in endometriosis. The increased TRPV1-positive nerve fibers may integrate various stimuli on peripheral terminals or primary sensory neurons and generate hyperalgesia in endometriosis. Upregulation and sensitization of TRPV1 in ectopic endometrium may facilitate the transmission of nociceptive information, thus contributing to the resultant pain response associated with ectopic endometrium implants of endometriosis.
